info.game_comments:
1991 Seniors Tournament final game 2.
Last game of Season 7.

(1, 1).clue: In a telegram on December 17, 1903, they wrote, "Success.  Four flights Thursday morning"

(2, 1).clue: American colony that was a "holy experiment" for the Society of Friends or Quakers

(3, 1).clue: 1936's "Modern Times" was the last film in which he appeared as the Little Tramp

(4, 1).clue: In 1927 this aviator was named Time magazine's first Man of the Year

(5, 1).clue: Founded by George Rogers Clark in 1778, this Kentucky city was named for a French monarch

(6, 1).clue: A.E. Housman wrote, "A tail behind, a trunk in front, complete the usual" one of these

(2, 2).clue: 1 of the 2 gospels in which a version of the Lord's Prayer appears

(4, 2).clue: This actor won a 1966 Tony for his one-man show, "Mark Twain Tonight!"

(5, 2).clue: This Nevada city calls itself "the biggest little city in the world"

(6, 2).clue: In this poem the borogoves were "all mimsy"

(2, 3).clue: This Christian church is headed by the patriarch of Alexandria, Egypt

(3, 3).clue: In studio logos, MGM had a lion & Republic one of these birds

(5, 3).clue: This Virginia port is headquarters for the Navy's Atlantic fleet

(6, 3).clue: Hilaire Belloc wrote, "When I'm dead, I hope it may be said: 'His sins were scarlet, but his books were'" this

(2, 4).clue: In Judaism it's the collective term for Rosh Hashanah & Yom Kippur

(3, 4).clue: This classic 1931 Cagney film was based on the John Bright story "Beer and Blood"

(4, 4).clue: A 1977 winner of the Pres. Medal of Freedom, Bruce Catton was a noted historian of this war
(4, 4).correct response: the Civil War, or the War between the States

(6, 4).clue: A piggy-wig in a wood sold his nose ring to this Edward Lear pair

(2, 5).clue: A religious retreat or commune in India; Gandhi had one at Wardha

(3, 5).clue: The 2 1939 films directed by Victor Fleming

(5, 5).clue: This largest city in Kansas is the world's top producer of general aviation aircraft

(6, 5).clue: He wrote, "Isn't it funny how a bear likes honey?  Buzz!  Buzz!  Buzz!  I wonder why he does?"

(1, 1).clue: This sports star tells all in his 1990 autobiography, "Bo Knows Bo"

(2, 1).clue: Founded in 1847, the Quincy Grammar School in this state was the USA's 1st graded elem. school

(3, 1).clue: The Italian part of this coastal resort area runs from the French border to Tuscany

(5, 1).clue: Name shared by a Beatles album title & a 1835 invention of Samuel Colt

(1, 2).clue: She dedicated her autobiography "To Walter Mondale for his faith & to John Zaccaro for his strength"

(2, 2).clue: The 1st schools in Alaska were established in the 1820s by this country

(3, 2).clue: Standard Italian came from the dialect used in this city by Dante, Petrarch & Boccaccio

(5, 2).clue: Adjective attached to Gustave Pasch's match & Walter Hunt's pin

(6, 2).clue: German spa town in the Black Forest region

(3, 3).clue: The 3 colors on the flag of Italy are red, white & this

(4, 3).clue: He called his "Bolero" a "piece for orchestra without music"

(5, 3).clue: In 1792 William Murdock was the first to use coal gas for this purpose

(2, 4).clue: Most of Aristotle's extant writings may have been notes for his lectures at this Athenian school
